content: ESM also enables the use of pass phrases instead of passwords. Like CP directory passwords, ESM passwords are limited to eight characters from a limited character set. Pass phrases (as implemented in RACF) support up to 100 characters from a wider character set. The use of pass phrases instead of passwords is an important consideration that allows z/VM to integrate into a wider enterprise security environment. Note: In the past, some ESMs (including RACF) did not use strong encryption methods to protect passwords; instead, they used “security by obscurity”. RACF now provides the KDFAES password encryption method, which uses much stronger encryption (backed by the hardware CPACF) to protect passwords and pass phrases. Enabling KDFAES also avoids a previous RACF restriction around pass phrase length. Pass phrases 9 - 13 characters were not supported in RACF without writing an exit to allow them.
